message.content:
cs.NI, cs.CR, cs.SY, cs.IT, cs.DC 

This paper deals with the design and evaluation of techniques for dynamically adapting the rate and power of broadcast packets in vehicular networks. The paper focuses on multi-application scenarios, where vehicles simultaneously run multiple applications with different requirements that vary with the vehicular context. This suggests that the paper is likely to belong to the Networking and Internet Architecture (cs.NI) sub-category, which deals with the design, analysis, and optimization of communication networks and protocols. The paper also deals with the security and reliability of vehicular networks, which suggests that it could also belong to the Cryptography and Security (cs.CR) sub-category. Moreover, the paper proposes techniques for controlling the transmission rate and power of broadcast packets, which suggests that it could also belong to the Systems and Control (cs.SY) sub-category. The paper also deals with the optimization of the channel load, which suggests that it could also belong to the Information Theory (cs.IT) sub-category. Finally, the paper deals with the design and evaluation of algorithms and protocols, which suggests that it could also belong to the Distributed, Parallel, and Cluster Computing (cs.DC) sub-category.
